From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: duchár

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From ducha +‎ -ar. Cf. French doucher.

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /duˈʃa(ʁ)/ [duˈʃa(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /duˈʃa(ʁ)/ [duˈʃa(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /duˈʃa(ɾ)/
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /duˈʃa(ʁ)/ [duˈʃa(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /duˈʃa(ɻ)/
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /duˈʃaɾ/
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /duˈʃaɾ/
    • (Northern Portugal) IPA(key): /duˈt͡ʃaɾ/
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /duˈʃa.ɾi/

  • Hyphenation: du‧char

Verb

[edit]

duchar (first-person singular present ducho, first-person singular preterite duchei, past participle duchado)

  1. (Brazil) to douche (to use a douche)

Conjugation

[edit]

2European Portuguese.

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From ducha. Cf. French doucher.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /duˈt͡ʃaɾ/ [d̪uˈt͡ʃaɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: du‧char

Verb

[edit]

duchar (first-person singular present ducho, first-person singular preterite duché, past participle duchado)

  1. to shower
  2. (reflexive) to take a shower

Conjugation

[edit]

gerund duchando

plural duchados duchadas

1Mostly obsolete, now mainly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tú form for the present subjunctive.
